channel.title: Differences in primitive code
channel.description:
What exactly are the differences in:
• Increment/decrement operators such as "++" and "--" and additive/subtraction operators such as "+" and "-"
• if(smartass == jerk), if(smartass != jerk), if(smartass.equals(jerk))
Also, with assignment operators are these the same? x += (x+y) and y += (y+x),
But if that was the case the subtraction way wouldn't be the same (as the negative would change up the answer each time) x -= (x-y) and y -= (y-x)
I'm new to java, and I'm really working hard to learn more about it.

item.title: Differences in primitive code
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Most decent compilers would just optimize both statements in the exact same way, it’d be a purely aesthetic difference. I’m not that familiar with the java compiler but as far as I know there could be a difference in the bytecode produced but the jvm would optimize this on runtime anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Differences in primitive code
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

there’s also postfix and prefix notation for ++ and --. those have minor differences.

Read full topic

item.title: Differences in primitive code
item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:5, topic:452778”][quote author=the elve age link=topic=555646.msg4067844#msg4067844 date=1344061013]
Really? According to one of the documents I was looking at, what I had appeared to be right. Can you answer anymore of the questions?
[/quote]

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reallybigindex.html covers this.
I refuse to spoonfeed and I’m sure you’re capable of sifting through it all to find your answer.[/quote]I don’t understand how this is spoon feeding when it’s asking general knowledge programming type questions, it doesn’t relate to anything or have any particular use other than pure knowledge. I understand there are documents (and trust me I’ve been reading them), but most of them tell you instead of explain everything and truthfully I’m a visual learning, and always have been.

I really do appreciate it Veer, thank you. I got it, one of the websites I was reading was wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Differences in primitive code
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:1, topic:452778”]What exactly are the differences in:

• Increment/decrement operators such as “++” and “–” and additive/subtraction operators such as “+” and “-”[/quote]
See the relevant Java Tutorial.
Note:

++ Increment operator; increments a value by 1
– Decrement operator; decrements a value by 1

Now, the difference between pre- and post-fix are in the evaluation of the expressions as part of larger ones. When used as standalone expression statements, they have the same net effect; when used as part of a more complex expression, it matters.
The increment/decrement operators can be applied before (prefix) or after (postfix) the operand. The code result++; and ++result; will both end in result being incremented by one. The only difference is that the prefix version (++result) evaluates to the incremented value, whereas the postfix version (result++) evaluates to the original value. If you are just performing a simple increment/decrement, it doesn't really matter which version you choose. But if you use this operator in part of a larger expression, the one that you choose may make a significant difference.
the elve age:

• if(smartass == jerk), if(smartass != jerk), if(smartass.equals(jerk))

The tutorial is here.

== equal to != not equal to
So, that being said, (a == b) and !(a != b) are equivalent; similarly, (a != b) and !(a == b) are as well. In the case you're comparing objects, these operators are used for [i]identity equality[/i]. If, instead, you want to figure [i]semantic equality[/i], use [url=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Object.html#equals(java.lang.Object)]Object.equals[/url]. For example, ("abc ".trim() == "abc") will evaluate to false, since the literal string object "abc" and the result of "abc ".trim() do [b]not[/b] share object identity, while ("abc ".trim().equals("abc")) will evaluate to true because they're still [b]meaningfully equivalent[/b].

[quote=“the elve age, post:1, topic:452778”]Also, with assignment operators are these the same? x += (x+y) and y += (y+x),

But if that was the case the subtraction way wouldn’t be the same (as the negative would change up the answer each time) x -= (x-y) and y -= (y-x)[/quote]
Neither of those examples do the same thing. x += (x + y) is shorthand (if we ignore type caveats for a second) for x = x + x + y, whereas y += (x + y) is y = y + x + y. Does that seem the same to you? Same logic for the subtraction ones.

Read full topic
